billEvents.eventText: REFERRED TO VETERANS, HOMELAND SECURITY AND MILITARY AFFAIRS

title: Provides specific legal authority for the division of military and naval affairs to initiate routine background checks about certain individuals
summary: Authorizes the adjutant general to investigate any applicant for a position within the division of military and naval affairs' law enforcement or youth programs; requires each applicant to submit sets of fingerprints for the purpose of conducting a criminal history search with the division of criminal justice services; provides that a record of a felony or misdemeanor conviction may be grounds for disqualification from such position.

       AN ACT to amend the military law, in relation to providing legal author-
         ity for obtaining background checks on individuals involved  with  law
         enforcement activities or community programs

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. Section 19 of the military law is amended by adding  a  new
    2  subdivision 5 to read as follows:
    3    5.  THE ADJUTANT GENERAL IS HEREBY AUTHORIZED TO HAVE INVESTIGATED ANY
    4  APPLICANT FOR A POSITION WITHIN  THE  DIVISION  OF  MILITARY  AND  NAVAL
    5  AFFAIRS'  LAW ENFORCEMENT OR YOUTH PROGRAMS. EACH APPLICANT SHALL SUBMIT
    6  SETS OF FINGERPRINTS IN THE FORM AND MANNER PRESCRIBED BY  THE  DIVISION
    7  OF CRIMINAL JUSTICE SERVICES. THE DIVISION OF MILITARY AND NAVAL AFFAIRS
    8  MAY  FORWARD THE FINGERPRINTS, ACCOMPANIED BY THE APPROPRIATE PROCESSING
    9  FEE, TO THE DIVISION OF CRIMINAL JUSTICE SERVICES  FOR  THE  PURPOSE  OF
   10  CONDUCTING  A  CRIMINAL  HISTORY  SEARCH AND RETURNING A REPORT THEREON.
   11  WHERE ANY SUCH APPLICANTS ARE FOUND TO HAVE A  RECORD  OF  A  FELONY  OR
   12  MISDEMEANOR CONVICTION IN THIS OR ANY OTHER STATE, IT MAY BE GROUNDS FOR
   13  DISQUALIFICATION  FOR  ANY  SUCH  POSITION. ANY APPLICANT WHO REFUSES TO
   14  PERMIT THE DIVISION OF MILITARY AND NAVAL AFFAIRS TO HAVE MATTERS INVES-
   15  TIGATED WHICH ARE NECESSARY FOR THE VERIFICATION OF HIS  OR  HER  QUALI-
   16  FICATIONS  OR OTHERWISE HAMPERS, IMPEDES, OR FAILS TO COOPERATE WITH THE
   17  AGENCY IN SUCH INVESTIGATION MAY BE LIKEWISE DISQUALIFIED.
   18    S 2. This act shall take effect immediately.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2281

TITLE OF BILL:
An act to amend the military law, in relation to providing legal author-
ity for obtaining background checks on individuals involved with law
enforcement activities or community programs

PURPOSE:
This bill will provide specific legal authority for the Division of
Military and Naval Affairs (DMNA) to initiate routine background checks
about certain individuals.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
The bill will add a new subdivision 5 to section 19 of the State Mili-
tary Law that sets forth the authority for DMNA regarding background
investigations.

EXISTING LAW:
Section 201-a of the Labor Law exempts the State from the prohibition
against fingerprinting potential employees. In addition, there are vari-
ous provisions of State law, and even the rules of the Civil Service
Commission, which permit examination of applicants either for licenses
issued by the State or employment with the State. For example, General
Municipal Law sections 191 and 481 permit background investigations to
determine whether commercial lessors for bingo operations, are individ-
uals of good moral character and have never been convicted of a crime;
General Business Law section 174 provides that applicants for licenses
thereunder can be investigated as to their responsibility and good char-
acter; and Civil Service Rules provide that applicants for Civil Service
appointment be of good moral character and habits and a satisfactory
reputation, and cannot impede or fail to cooperate with investigations
as to such attributes. DMNA is simply seeking similar investigative
authority.

STATEMENT IN SUPPORT:
The Division of Military and Naval Affairs is responsible for the opera-
tion of the State Emergency Management Office, as well as the readiness
of the Organized Militia for its many individuals affiliated with DMNA
become involved with the handling of millions of dollars in Federal
and/or State appropriations, have access to confidential military infor-
mation, or operate DMNA programs for which it is important to the State,
from a liability standpoint, that the individuals so involved are of
good moral character. For example, just one of our on-going programs has
given the National Guard an important support role for law enforcement
agencies in drug interdiction. As part of this program, National Guard
personnel are involved with the detection of border crossings, the
search of vehicles crossing borders, the seizure of being privy to
information about law enforcement activities. When bringing people into
this program, we wish to have an appropriate examination of their back-
grounds. We have a similar concern for individuals who perform duty as
air base security guards. In a variety of other National Guard programs

we are becoming extensively involved with youth who are at risk because
of a community environment of drugs and crime.  Our people operating
these programs may be part-time members of the National Guard, full-time
employees of DMNA, or volunteers having no formal employment status with
our agency. Regardless of their status, we would nevertheless want to
examine the character of individuals who are going to be involved with
children and young people in these programs, so as to protect the chil-
dren from harm and the State from liability.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
The level of fiscal support required to implement this bill, for the
first and subsequent years of funding, is deemed to be very minor
because of the relatively cheap cost of background investigations and
the small number of personnel who would be sought to be investigated
under this authority for our agency. Also, the costs in this regard may
be passed on to the applicants.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately.
